This is my second 30 day YWA challenge and I am loving it!  Prior to this, I had never practiced yoga. Adriene is the right kind of teacher for me - she keeps it real, challenging and fun! The Day 6- Core practice was rather intense and my core is burning,  but I was able to power through it and I feel accomplished. I am thoroughly enjoying the growth and daily commitment to better myself - mind and body. Namaste Global YWA community!
A nice core workout today 🙂 it felt really good 👍 looking forward to tomorrow 👍😀✌️

I've been doing sore focus work on and off the last three years the try to hold a rotating vertebra in place and this was much kinder than my usual workouts, while a;so being effective.  I'll probably be back for this day on it's own as needed.

Girl on fire! Love that song! Day 6 complete... Im adding this Challenge to my morning yoga and in the evening I'm doing a core/abs with an evening practice. I've never felt better, thank you so much Adriene! ♥️ You're such a beautiful gift to so many people! God Bless you! Namaste 🙏🏽 🌹🤗

I don't know if it is this dedicate journey is really the reason but I've been crying big time the last two days. After not crying for for a while now. Weird enough I cried around the same time, around ten in the morging both days. After yesterday I felt releaved. After today I almost couldn't stop  crying and I feel drained. Just so sad and drained and I don't know way. So far this 30 days journey has made me feel more calm and at easy. Just the reasons why I started this journey in the first place, so thank you Adriene for all your work.

I LOVE core day! Thanks for bringing the heat today, Adriene!

Brief testimonial: I first started "yoga with Adriene" three years ago. I always had the best intentions, but I never got past day 6 in any of the 30 day challenges. This year, in January, I made it through my first 30 days. Then, another, and another, etc. I've done a yoga with Adriene 30 day challenge every month this year, and I am SO much stronger, happier, and more peaceful than I was before.

Don't give up, you will see results and you'll feel amazing!

Thank you Adriene! 💚💚💚

minute 12, coming out of the down dog, looking at you talk about your wrist, briefly closing my eyes and I saw a negative image of you and benji! not the whole room but just the two of you in a rectangle. how beautiful!!

When I saw the word "core" I got terrified, because I'm not good at this kind of practices, and I didn't really like the other 5 days. I walked a lot today and thought that I will suck at this one too. But this is now one of my favorite practices! I don't know why, maybe I'm getting stronger or it's this one particular practice, but usually when it comes to the boat pose I start to shake and feel frustrated. Now I embraced the shake and felt those energy vibrations all over my body, I didn't give up halfway and made it through! The only problem is that I can't get rid of this tension in the neck and the throat when I excersise on my back.
Thanks for this amazing practice, I will come back to it later!

I’ve been doing these videos every day on my tv for about six months and today was the first time my dog noticed Benji. Which is pretty funny considering he was just chilling in the back today. Lots of head turning and whining 😂
I felt all the pressure on my shoulders, not wrists.
Are the shoulders supposed to hurt? Or am I doing something horribly wrong?
@Abby C sorry, but the shoulders still hurt like crazy. 🤕

make sure you’re pressing up out from your shoulders rather than collapsing into them, almost like you’re drawing the tops of the shoulders down and really ground into your fingers. hope that helped <3

this was somehow harder than my ab workout! i think the more integrated engagement and all the stillness in these positions makes it more challenging, I love it! thanks adriene

I have my problems with Dedicate, not gonna lie. It's the third 30 day yoga challenge in a row and somehow Home and True were so much easier for me, but today was amazing. I had a 'problem' with my belly my whole life, but before stepping on the mat today I realized that I was looking forward to day six. It does feel so good to feel the strength in my core and finally starting to think positive on this area after twenty years of just negative thoughts and comments. At the at home yoga practice I don't have to proof how many of this I can do or how long I can do that. I just can follow what feels good and that it amazing. Thank you so much Adriene.

I’ve never been able to fully complete day 6 before. I always give up and start hating myself. Today, I dug in and made it happen. I just accepted the burn as emerging growth, met myself where I am, did the best I could. I ended this practice in the best kind of tears.

I came to 'dedicate' after finishing 'home'. I can honestly say, day 6 of 'home' felt so difficult. I felt pretty defeated afterwards, but it didn't stop me. Completing day 6 of 'dedicate' has seriously made me understand the huge physical change I have under gone in the last month. Although this flow was hard, I could do it. Unlike the day 6 of 'home', where I gave up half way through, this time I pushed myself and I feel so good now I have done it. Thank you Adriene, for helping me build strength and gain confidence. I am so excited for the days ahead. Namaste.

I first started exercising in February 2020, Home series. Since then I have finished Yoga camp and now I'm at Dedicate. The difference is HUGE. Nothing ever could make me calm myself like this. You are a living saint doing this at the time when nothing is free, and the quality of our lives is ruled by money. Can't thank you enough, and I can't emphasize enough the impact you are having. I wish you all the happiness and love in the world!
Sending the love to you , Benji and the crew!

Adriene: Day 6 is core
Me: Noooooooo

But heyo it wasn’t so bad. I noticed the negativity as I was getting on the mat & just reminded myself that this is not about copying Adriene(or anyone)’s exact moves or getting sculpted abs. It’s many things; it’s about giving it a shot, taking myself less seriously, pushing myself, meeting my appropriate edge, breathing, growing, being mindful, going home, dedicating. 💕
This wasn't as hard as I thought it was going to be! Usually when I give up, I give up. But this time, I took little breaks then got back into it!

Here's to my year of yoga challenge to myself. Gratitude spilling across the Atlantic Ocean from the sunny southeast of Ireland x

After my pregnancy and Caesarian I haven’t practiced yoga for a while. For the first time in three years I missed the 30-days. I’ve started the Dedicate series last week, 8 months after giving birth. Right away I remembered why I wanted to start yoga again. My head cleared and my body relaxed. Even without sleep, without proper me-time, with a baby on the mat, I breathed love in and love out. However, my wrists started to hurt real bad, so before today’s practice I watched and practiced the Yoga for wrist pain. Imagine my surprise when this video zoomed in on the wrists as well! It felt like it was meant to be. I’m here and I’m stronger than I thought I would be. I made it to the end of the practice and I’ve never been more grateful for my body and what it’s been through the past year(s). Thanks Adriene, for giving me back myself. I’m looking forward to the rest of the practices and can’t wait for the new series in January!

Today was hard, but I completed the whole thing and it made feel really good. In 2 weeks I'll turn 59, and about 15 years ago I was so sick with Lupus I was in bed unable to move. I quit the gym and started to do yoga by myself at home. But it got horribly boring and difficult to challenge myself. And I was lucky to find Yoga with Adriene! Today it was the first day I really felt challenged, but I learned a great lesson: keep your belly button close to your spine, keep your lower back close to the floor. This was such an amazing piece of knowledge. Adrienne, you inspire me to feel gratitude for the things that sometimes I took for granted. Now, I am always always grateful for being able to move my body, , my wonderful belly that carried three kids and could do the core yoga today, my wonderful boobs that nourished three babies, my whole wonderful body that enjoys yoga with wonderful Adrienne every morning. A million thanks!
Oh Adriene - you are just wonderful. I enjoy these minutes with you very much. Thankyou.

Day 6 in the books! This was for sure the most challenging day for me so far. My core has never burned (in a good way) the way it did today. I had forgotten to love it for what it is and as it is because it is a vital piece of me. Thank you Adriene for being a constant reminder of patience and self love. I cannot thank you enough for this series - I started this journey thinking I didn’t like yoga and because of you I’ve come to understand yoga on a different and deeper level, making me a lover of yoga!

Thank you for another great class! A couple of things. I have been following the 30 day practice from day 1, which I am enjoying. One thing though - I haven't Heard you mention for people to breathe through the nose as I hear in all classes I go to - is there a reason?
And I have carpal tunnel syndrome, thanks to over doing it with handstands a couple of years ago, I was 50 at the time and it's really messed with my practice and I now find it difficult to stay in downward facing dog for more than 3 breaths or any wrist weight bearing postures. I like your instruction to 'claw the mat' which I've been mindfully doing all week, the great news is I haven't woken up once from tingling hands this week and my wrists actually seem to be managing okay. Fingers crossed that you're instruction is going to be the beginning of the end of my wrist problems. Thank you ❤️

Your so awesome adriene I love this practice ❤️❤️❤️ thank you

When I first did day 6, I was crying from anger. I was soooo mad, I was swearing and hating you "how do you think it is possible?" and the only thing that made me through the day's practice was the thing, that I felt, I love you Adriene, and I trust you so much, that I could hold to this trust, that it's good to do this, if you tell me so. The only thing that led me through my hate and anger was love and trust. And you know, though it may sound strange, it is how love works. It holds all the paradoxes in an embrace of acceptence. So after the first time, I wrote it into my diary, to repeat it 2 weeks later. And this is my second time, I'm here.  14 days later (doing everyday the yoga), it's still hard, but no anger and much much more strength. The only time, when tears were coming, when I released from one hard posture. It was tears from relief and gratitude for the ground to hold me. Quite a change, hm?! Thank you so much for doing it, for giving your shine and love for us. Much Love! <3
day 6 - still going strong thank you :)

Day 6 on the books! When I saw it was core today, I was excited and fearful because my stomach area is so weak and sticks out. I couldn't do all the positions exactly, but continued and tried to keep up the best I could. The other challenge I experienced today was laying on my back, it feels stiff and sore and like I could not get flat, kinda like its full of inflammation or kinda like I have fat pockets back there and when I lay flat it squishes and I can't get flat. I continued with the lesson and the breathing helped me release and the rubbing of my stomach also helped. It was like I was releasing old ideas, thoughts, and build up of the stress out of my body and praising myself of what I was able to accomplish today.  I am 52, long time smoker, quit now 2 mos.and haven't exercised in a few years, plus I've never done yoga before (My old idea about yoga is its too hard and I am not flexible enough, I am too out of shape to do it) these last 6 sessions have changed my thinking into Yes I can do this and so happy I found Adriene to teach me. I finished feeling confident and praising my body thanking it for staying strong for me when I haven't treated it with care in so long; ready to do more strengthing each day I practice my yoga. I feel as though the dedicate 30 days is building upon each day of strength and confidence. I've never felt so good and want to keep working on strengthing my body until I found yoga with Adriene.

To be completely honest, I didn't want to do this practice when I saw the word core in it. Whenever I tried to train my core, I felt all weak because I couldn't keep up with the speed or couldn't do certain exercises but today was different. Even though I still couldn't do all exercises due to horrible pain in the neck when I lift my head, instead of feeling my muscles working, I didn't beat myself up for it but instead was proud of had my core has done up to that point! I felt really happy with my stomach for being as strong as it was right now, a feeling I had never really had before. Thank you Adriene for allowing me to be in touch with my feelings and my body more and to appreciate what is already there instead of feeling the need to be a certain way.

I wasn't going to comment at first but maybe someone else will see this and feel better because of it.
I couldn't get through most of this video without crying. I found it incredibly hard. I've been doing yoga pretty regularly for about 3 years now and despite Adriene's loving words, I'm still terrified of Day 6 and of core. I usually skip these videos altogether or don't even get halfway because I give up on myself.
Now I never cry on the mat. But halfway through there I was, crying because I couldn't do it and I didn't feel strong enough or brave enough etc. But I did it anyway. I had my moment, I kept the video going and I tried to pick back up where I could for as much as I could. And that's okay. And when I got to the end of the video I went and cried some more.
I realised then that I wasn't crying because I couldn't do it, I was crying because I made myself feel so worthless and bad about it. For too long, my first instinct has been to hate myself, to feel less than other people, than myself. So here's me not shying away from that and saying it's okay to feel bad and like you're doing it wrong. You're not. It's just part of figuring out how to love yourself.
So here's to you, and me, loving ourselves throughout. Namaste.

I cried, too.

@unboredhands hey just want you to know theres no need to beat yourself up over this. I still struggle doing any type of core/ab workout and I sometimes feel the same way - like this just isn't for me. But we learn a little bit each time, even if it's just knowing where our boundaries are. If you don't feel up to this, I suggest getting into a restorative pose that works for you,like extended childs pose and focus on your breathing and some positive thoughts on what you CAN do/accomplish/control. It's okay to sit out a move, a session or a whole day. You have so much power! I hope you wont give up and try the next one tomorrow or when you feel up to it. Sending you lots of good vibes ♡

Honestly this is one of the first videos I completely abandoned and made me rethink whether this was the right series for me. This was so discouraging (and I say this as someone that had done a large number of these videos.) This one wasn't for me and felt so out of place. It wasn't a "challenge" - it was impossible, it was pretty much just throwing pie in my face and laughing at me and calling me a fatass. If I had chosen to start with this series as an intro to yoga, if I encountered this on day 6, I would likely never do yoga again. As someone that is a little larger, I've struggled so much my whole life doing "physical" things and was often reminded I was dragging everyone down, that no one had time or cared that it sometimes took me way more work to get to a "easy" exercise that is easier when your weight is distributed differently. I hate that this video is making me seriously reconsider this whole series. I honestly don't think I could every do these moves without losing a massive amount of weight and even the arthritis in my toes is making me question if weight loss would even help.

I would not put such advanced moves within the first 10 minutes of a video. Like I said, I'm seriously reconsidering whether this is the right path for me. I'm here because I want to learn, but jumping so far ahead with no warning, with it being day 6 out of 30, I feel so unsupported, so discouraged, and like I just walked into a class for a pHD program and being expected to do the work when skill-wise, I'm still in pre-school and I don't see the path between here and there.

How can I do this without taking the strain in my neck? I know my core needs a lot of work, but I make my already sore neck worse a;most before my core does anything, especially when we lift the head off the mat... I don't want to make anything worse, but also need to do the exercises! Please help!

@Carmen Kälin  Thank you :) I was trying that, my neck still activates even though I'm trying to hold it, it won't just rest... Maybe part of it is just intention, and it will just do what it needs to do over time. Who knows? ;) I'll keep holding my head though, and hope for the best. Thanks again :)

Try using your hands as a "neck hammock". Place this hammock where the head and the neck join (try different positions to see how they feel) and dont push up your head when doing the pulses but rather rest it in your hands when you lift up. Also do this when the instruction is to reach towards your feet or something similar - you can do all these exercises with your hands supporting your neck and head! Hope this helps! :)

Today was hard. Physically and mentally. I've never felt my core was strong, I've never really trusted my core or the muscles there despite knowing logically how much of my strength comes from there.
I struggled with this practice. I struggled with day 6 last year but this year I knew what was coming and I thought I was mentally and physically prepared because I'm stronger and more capable than I was this time last year. I was not. Never in any practice have I been so stuck between "I can but I can't". I was okay for the hovers and the three-legged dogs because I felt like I could trust my legs and my arms to support what my core couldn't, I had a safety net. Then I got onto my back and started working. I've never felt so weak during my practice. Not last year when I was new or in any other workout I've done in my life. Laying there trying to hold my legs and my shoulders up and knowing logically that I can do this, that I've done it before, that there's no pressure to look good or get it perfect, and that I could take breaks if I needed to, but feeling like I was fighting with myself to get there and that feeling of weakness through my core, through my very centre, in comparison to the rest of my body was so in conflict with my logical mind that I felt like I was going to shake apart.
I'm not gonna lie. I burst into tears. Free flowing, lying on my back in the middle of the floor sobbing because the conflict in me felt like it was gonna break me. Stuck between "I can but I can't".
Well I can, I did. I took my break. I cried, I let myself rest. Gave myself a hot minute of feeling like crap, dried my tears and then I rewound to where I fell and I started again. And I did it. I finished the practice, I did the last little obliques work, I reached towards the end of my mat, I put in that extra work to prove that I cam capable of getting back up after falling.
I want to say 'thank you', Adriene. Truly. From the bottom of my heart. Thank you for doing these videos. Thank you for being patient and kind and caring. For making me and others feel like it's okay to fall and that everything is just practice and that we are perfectly imperfect and capable. Thank you for being there and teaching us and guiding us into taking care of all parts of ourselves.
You probably won't see this, and it's super long so I won't be disappointed if you don't read it but I wanted to tell you and anyone else who reads this what this practice was for me. That sometimes these practices are hard not just on your body but on your mind as well, but that we are all capable of getting back up after falling down.
Thank you.
Namaste

by walking a lot. if you are close to the nature, go for a long walk - by yourself, when you need to be by yourself. with somebody when you want to be with somebody. the food is mostly a habit - you sit in front of a computer and probably grab food because it's a stress relief. instead of food put a glass of water or, even better, a cup of green tea in your reach. have reaching for that glass replace reaching out for food. allow yourself a bad food day, but try eating healthy. don't forget, a large amount of food is still full of calories, no matter how healthy that food is. lastly, don't stop eating or restrict your diet to a thousand calories or something - you won't have energy to move. eat less and make sure that you burn more calories than you eat. and don't expect quick results - it takes time.

When I first began doing yoga I thought my wrists were weak. I had trouble holding down dog for long at all, as my wrists would hurt, especially as down dog would be repeated through a session. I didn't even have any thoughts that it might be that my wrists could get stronger. I really thought they were just weak and I was bummed because I didn't think I'd ever be able to fully do yoga with ease in terms of any asanas using wrist action. But, to my happy surprise, one day I noticed my wrists no longer hurt or were sore and I could do down dog for however long and however many times it would be repeated in a session. I would push my wrists to hold a pose longer than it felt safe to back in those earlier days of yoga, but just holding the poses however long felt safe did lead to my wrists getting very strong and now they are not an issue. Namaste.
Bella Jordans I thought it was because I was a hairstylist and they were overused and not very strong. I’m encouraged that they will get stronger with more work!

@Christina Keasler What I had to do was simply hold a pose such as down dog as long as I could but without it getting to the point it hurt. I'd hold a pose that put pressure on my wrists such as down dog a little longer once it got to the point my wrists began to feel "worked" (like I'd hold just a little more to try to strengthen) but I'd go into extended child's pose once my wrist felt like any longer would become too much (and if the instructor was still having a pose like down dog held by everyone else) and I'd just rest in child's pose until a different asana was cued. I hadn't even hoped it would change for me in terms of how my wrists were feeling regarding this and then, one fine day, I noticed I could hold down dog longer without even feeling like my wrists were being "worked"! I was very pleased. Now I can hold something like down dog for quite some time and my wrists don't feel strained or sore at all.

In terms of digging in fingers, the proper alignment (as I'd heard it explained repeatedly in classes led by an instructor who was a stickler for alignment) for the hands is to think in terms of pressing into that knuckle on your palm that's right under your index finger and then coming down along that edge of the hand (to the fleshy part by your thumb) and then pressing into the knuckle on the palm just under the pinky and coming down that edge of the hand on the outer edge of your palm. You then "rest" the two inner knuckles down that are in between those to anchoring knuckles. The rest of the palm (the center portion) is a little hollowed in shape so the whole palm isn't smashing into the floor. A friend of mine became yoga instructor certified by that same teacher who knows alignment like she channels it or something and she went over the proper hand alignment, again and again, stating that if it is done incorrectly carpel tunnel can be brought on by holding poses too much that put pressure on the wrists if the hand position is not done correctly. At least that is what that instructor said about it. It may or may not be factual but I have to say I've seen many yoga certified instructors who actually don't do the alignment's properly (on much of any pose) and I imagine how adept an instructor is with that is largely determined by how well their instructor understood it, taught it, and then how adept the subsequent instructors are at taking it on. (It took me a little while to get this hand placement down. I had to think about it over and over as I'd place my hands down. In time, it became natural. It might also be a part in why my wrists did better over time, but I do know they really did get stronger by repeatedly doing yoga over some months.

One thing I've noticed about my body, in general, is if I'm eating animal products, sugars, and processed foods I have a lot more aches in my body and migraines. And, most helpfully, I've noticed if I have a lot of fresh-made juice that I make each day (like 2 or 3 16 oz servings each day - I'd make some juices that were all green - like cucumber, celery, ginger, or cucumber, celery, kale or parsley and others would be something like orange, apple, lemon, or watermelon, or watermelon, cucumber and mint {super yummy} and I'd have a green one at least one time each day) I have relatively no aches and pains and hardly get headaches. I've gone back and forth on my diet many times over the years and this pattern began to emerge consistently. (I typically dilute my green juices with an equal amount of water, and kale hardly tastes like anything so you get tons of nutrients without much flavor. By diluting the green juice it tastes a lot nicer, in my opinion.)

I also tend to be in far happier moods (thoughts/emotions) when having all that juice and eliminating the things mentioned in the first group. It's like the foods that are far more natural and mostly raw seem to support everything (physical, mental, emotional) while the other side seems to cause issues to varying degrees in all areas as well. It does take some time to notice the improvement if going on the juices and changing the diet. It's not like I can ever tell right away. I usually can begin to notice improvement after about 2 weeks and it keeps improving from there over several more weeks.

A tip also - juicing and raw or vegan foods tend to have people thinking it costs so much to eat like that, but my S.O. and I have noticed over the years of going back and forth dietarily that it's actually cheaper to have all the juices and produce because, once our bodies are acclimated, we are so nourished that we hardly need any food and we, therefore, don't keep feeling like we need a snack here and there and another meal over there, etc. (It only cost a little more at first when adding the juices, as we need to eat more at first until our bodies adjust. Then, the price drops significanltly.) We've also noticed tremendous health support from Dr. Schultze's Super Food. I love putting some of that in my citrus based juices or banana berry smoothies I make fresh (though the first time I mixed it in my juice I didn't care for it much but I quickly began to crave it - probably because my body wanted more!)

Every year for the past four years, I've started the year doing this 30 day yoga challenge. The first year, I'd lost a fiance who was living 5,000 miles overseas. The second year, I'd started seeing someone new and dove into it quickly. The third year, we'd just moved in together, I was recovering from a broken my arm, and our relationship was falling apart. Year four, I'm crying every day doing this damn yoga because I finally found the strength to move out and begin moving on. From all of it.

These 30 day beginning-of-the-year resets are always reminding me that life has ups (like my dope chaturanga dandasana) and downs (like that awful hovering-three-legged-posed! wtf!), and that in the midst of one I can remember the other to find balance. I cried in each of the last three videos because you're always reminding me how to find love in myself and for the fourth year in a row when I needed to be guided there most. When I'm too depressed (and poor) to make it to the yoga studio and be social with hundreds of Whole Foods yogi types, these videos give me a means to care for my body, my soul, and my self. I can't thank you enough for these videos, Adriene (and YWA team). They make me laugh, they make me cry, and they make me wake up looking forward to something every day. So grateful to be able to start each year this way!

I am so grateful for this challenge and for myself for 'dedicating' my time and energy to be here. a couple days ago someone left a comment about how yoga has helped their PTSD. I am so thankful for that comment. Today my husband and I were in a car crash. we are bruised and sore and possible bruised or broken ribs. Throughout this experience I breathed. I just breathed. That comment came to my mind and helped me feel more at ease. I also remembered and felt the support from everyone here in this yoga community and knew I was supported and cared about. I couldn't wait to get home to experience today's yoga journey. You are all friends I haven't met yet. I have always loved and remember when Adriene says 'lots of love in, and lots of love out'. People always tell you too imagine good things in and bad things out but I never connected with it. One of the first yoga videos I did of Adriene's she said lots of love and lots of love out and it rung true to my soul and has been with me since. I am a being of love who accepts love and shares love. And every day I find new meaning in those words. Thank you Adriene. Thank you friends. Thank you Benji.

I was extremely close to “letting myself off the hook” today and skipping yoga. My Monday was a shitstorm. I woke up to my cat peeing blood and have spent the last 9 or so hours back and forth to the animal hospital and on the phone with veterinarian. We’ve ruled some scary things out, and my sweet boy Charlie is snoozing while his antibiotics kick in. I just finished this yoga session and I feel so much better for it. Interesting how skipping something like this can feel like something you “deserve” to be able to do on a tough day, when what you actually need is to do the complete opposite and follow through, to feel better. ✌️ Feeling grateful tonight for family support, furry friends and Adriene.

Does anyone know if its okay to go onto my fists during table top? Like good for the position/connection/flow? My right wrist has been an unhappy camper for like almost a year now and I really struggle with too much time in table top specifically

I have the same issue with my right wrist and on some days can't even get it bent for tabletop because of the pain. In those cases my yoga teacher once told me to go on the forearms. It will be a bit of a different pose but one that also strengthens the arms (which will help the wrists in the long run) and puts absolutely no pressure on the wrists. It feels weird at first but it's even a good practice for headstand, so I am telling myself even though I can't do the tabletop I will be able to do a headstand eventually ;D

Today as I readied for Day 6, I already felt a positive energy and was eager and willing, which is great in contrast to days that PTSD got me down. I love how Adriene adds variations to poses that we already such as lifting the knee with the other leg extended. It made me feel challenged and strong to get this done. The rest of the core exercise was challenging and rewarding. I realize I need to work on drawing in my navel to my spine. Adriene, your core practices have really changed how I use to do core exercises. It was such a slog in the past. Now it is a loving practice in which I am focused on the present. Having a strong core and abs are a result of being present in the practice, as opposed to the manner in which I use to only focus on the end results. Thank you!

I get super anxious whenever we work the stomach muscles. I'll have to pause not so much because of strength (well, that too at times) but anxiety. Has anyone else ever experienced this? WHY am I experiencing it and HOW can I get past it?

You know the core practice is good when you can hear your neighbor laugh at the ridiculous noises you're making! "now, gently reach up toward your toes".... "OOOOOOOOH" ahaha But I feel so alive right now. Knowing that no matter what comes up on the mat I am here for me and it's all good; even the days when my mind struggles to settle down, or when I can't get into a pose I've done a million times before, staying on the mat IS an act of love and I know that whatever happens is meant to be. I'm learning how to apply this to my time off the mat and it's full of hits and misses and it's harder to not blame yourself when you feel you should already know better... but I'm not letting that discourage me :D
Thank you for sharing! Really enjoyed it.

I love how vulnerable and loving this practice allows me to be. Today my mantra was 'My body loves me' and when we were doing more intense core work or rubbing our bellies it turned to 'My stomach loves me' and I felt myself keep replying 'and I love my body/my stomach'. Somehow this allowed me do the WHOLE practice (which I had been dreading). Everytime I breathed in love and breathed out love, I was so aware of the positivity and love of our community. Tears of happiness as we bowed namaste to one another.    I'm a sap, but I'm a happy sap 🌳😂. Namaste ❤

I think this is from trying to follow along with you Adriene as best I can with the breath. Good morning/evening/night to you all. I would like to thank Ms Mishler for this excellent work and content. I  do not normally share my views but this channel has been an anchor giving me stability and a reason to keep coming back. My story is probably alot like many who find themselves here, due to my job I herniated my L4 & L3 in 2011. The pain is a constant, unless it flares and learning that the pain will not dissipate can be a hard thing to comprehend let alone accept. Some days the pain beats me but more often than not I can stay above it. Please excuse another maritime metaphor but  this practice encourages me to kick harder against the waves of pain and to feel stronger. My practice is done by myself and even if I have not yet looked for a more meaningful, deeper connection, it  still gives me strength developing and strengthening my lower back and opening up my spine. Thank you for the instruction and the encouragement. I wish you all well in your pursuits in 2019.

This kills my neck...anyone else?? Am I doing it wrong?
@holly galvez You wouldn't think breathing and focusing on your neck would be difficult! lol But for me apparently it is. :)

Sometimes it helps to think of lifting your chest/ribs to your knees instead of your head. That way you focus on lifting your whole upper body with your core, instead of trying to pull your head up with your hands or tucking your chin in.

@ArtGirl Creations yea... I've been there! Just focus in the contraction of the abdomen and don't force your neck. If you can't lift as high as it should be just do your thing, you'll get there in time.
@Gabriela F Thank you for the reply. I will try to keep that in mind! In the moment all I can think is ahhhhh my neck! lol

It used to happen to me too. Keep your neck straight as Adriene says and try not lifting by tensing the shoulders but using your belly!! It's hard I know, but you'll get there with time and your neck will be thankful!! Good luck with it, see you on Day 7!😘

Today was the first time I woke up and felt some apprehension rather than excitement to come on the mat. I had to work very late to finish a project, I'll have to work very late again today because of an exam tomorrow morning, and I thought "my core is so weak, this is going to be hell, is it really the right choice to do this today instead of getting an extra 30 minutes to sleep or work"? But then I realized two things: 1) I was scared of "failing" at yoga.Which is ridiculous, because you can't "fail" or "do badly" at a practice, you can only get stronger and feel better. And anyway, this is Adriene! I trust her, and I trust the process. 2) Yes, showing up at my mat just for me, even when it isn't easy is the right choice. It is self-care and we need some more than ever when we feel tired, stressed and overwhelmed. So I did it, I got on the mat, and I actually enjoyed myself a whole lot! I even let out a surprise laugh at the one-knee hover because of how different it felt from both 3-legged dog and the normal hovering on both knees. I am so happy and energised right now! So anyway, this extra long comment just to say: to anyone feeling like I was today: let go of that fear, that frustration. Trust the process and go in your practice being kind to yourself, without judgement. It will be amazing. Thank you Adriene, you are magic <3
The satisfaction that comes with just showing up for ourselves ANYWAY, despite ANYTHING that could be going on... it makes it all so worth it!

Good luck on your exam!
